{
  "article_text": [
    "cluster algebras were introduced by s. fomin and a. zelevinsky in [ fz02 , fz03 ] .",
    "they are a class of commutative algebras which was shown to be connected to various areas of mathematics like , for instance , combinatorics , lie theory , poisson geometry , teichmller theory , mathematical physics and representation theory of algebras .",
    "a cluster algebra is generated by a set of variables , called _ cluster variables _ , obtained recursively by a combinatorial process known as _ mutation _ starting from a set of _ initial _ cluster variables . explicit computation of cluster variables is difficult and has been extensively studied , see [ ars10 , adss11 , ad11 , ar12 , bmrrt06 , bmr08 ] .    in order to compute cluster variables , one may use _ friezes _ , which were introduced by coxeter [ c71 ] and studied by conway and coxeter [ cc73-i , ii ] .",
    "various relationships are known between friezes and cluster algebras , see [ cc06 , m11 , pr08 , ars10 , bm12 , d10 , ad11 , adss12 , ar12 ] .",
    "the present work is motivated by the use of friezes to compute cluster variables and is inspired by the results in [ ars10 , ar12 , ma13 ] giving an explicit formula as a product of @xmath6 matrices for all cluster variables in coefficient - free cluster algebras of types @xmath7 and @xmath8 , thus explaining at the same time the laurent phenomenon and positivity .",
    "our objective here is to show that similar techniques can be used for computing cluster variables in coefficient - free cluster algebras of type @xmath9 .    in this paper",
    ", we establish a relation between the values of a frieze of type @xmath9 and some values of an @xmath1-tiling @xmath2 associated with a particular quiver of type @xmath7 . for this",
    "we associate with each quiver of type @xmath0 a particular quiver of type @xmath3 .",
    "this correspondence allows us to obtain an algorithm for computing cluster variables of a cluster algebra of type @xmath0 independently of each other , that is without iteration .",
    "the article is organized as follows . in section @xmath10 , we recall some basic notions on @xmath1-tilings associated with a quiver of type @xmath7 . in section @xmath11 , we set preliminaries on friezes of type @xmath9 and establish a correspondence between a frieze of type @xmath9 and an @xmath1-tiling associated with a particular quiver of type @xmath7 . in section @xmath12 , we give an algorithm to compute all the cluster variables in a cluster algebra associated with a quiver of type @xmath9 .",
    "in this section we recall some notions on @xmath1-tilings and apply them to a quiver of type @xmath7 according to [ ars10 ] .",
    "let @xmath13 be a field and @xmath14 the discrete plane .",
    "we call @xmath1-tiling of the plane a map @xmath15 such that for any @xmath16 @xmath17 +    the following example represents an @xmath1-tiling with @xmath18",
    ". +    @xmath19 +    the @xmath1-tiling is an extension to the whole plane of the frieze introduced by coxeter [ c71 ] and studied by conway and coxeter [ cc73-i , ii ] .",
    "let @xmath20 be a finite acyclic ( containing no oriented cycles ) quiver with @xmath21 the set of its points and @xmath22 the set of its arrows and @xmath13 a field .",
    "the translation quiver @xmath23 associated with @xmath20 ( see [ ass - viii.1.1 ] ) consists of two sets : the set of points @xmath24 and the set of arrows + @xmath25 let us define a frieze associated with the quiver @xmath20 .    in the translation quiver @xmath23 ( see [ ass - viii.1.1 ] ) ,",
    "let us replace the points @xmath26 by their images under a frieze function @xmath27 : @xmath28 defined for some initial values @xmath29 as follows : @xmath30 where the product is taken over the arrows ( see [ ars10 - 2 ] ) .",
    "the resulting translation quiver with values associated with its vertices is called a frieze .",
    "+ in general we associate a _",
    "boundary _ to an @xmath1-tiling .",
    "we call boundary a bi - infinite sequence @xmath31 with @xmath32 and @xmath33 for all @xmath34 .",
    "coefficients @xmath35 equal to one are usually omitted in the sequence representing a boundary .",
    "each boundary may be embedded into the euclidean plane in the following way : the @xmath36 ( or @xmath37 ) determine the horizontal ( or vertical , respectively ) segments of a discrete path , that is @xmath36 ( or @xmath37 ) corresponds to a segment of the form [ @xmath38 $ ] ( or @xmath39 $ ] , respectively ) in the plane .",
    "the variables @xmath40 become thus labels of the vertices of a discrete path .",
    "a boundary is called _ admissible _ if none of the sequences @xmath41 and @xmath42 is ultimately constant .",
    "given an admissible boundary @xmath43 embedded in the plane , let @xmath44 be a point in @xmath14 . then the _ word associated with _",
    "@xmath44 is the portion of the boundary @xmath43 delimited by the horizontal and vertical projections of the point @xmath45 on the boundary @xmath43 .",
    "the following example shows an embedded boundary and how to associate a word with a point in @xmath14 .",
    "the word associated with the point @xmath46 is @xmath47 .",
    "+ @xmath48\\ar@{-}[r ]    &      c_{4}\\ar@{-}[r ]   &   \\ar@{.}[r ]     &   &          \\\\ &   &    &    &       & c_{2}\\ar@{-}[d ]      &    &        &     &   &    \\\\ &    &   & c_{-1}\\ar@{-}[r]\\ar@{-}[d ] &   c_{0}\\ar@{-}[r ] &   c_{1 }   &    &    & &   \\\\ &     &   & c_{-2}\\ar@{-}[d ] & &    &    p\\ar@{.}[uuu]\\ar@{.}[lll ]    &       &    & \\\\ &     &   & \\ar@{.}[d ] &    &    &       &       &    & \\\\ & & & & & & & & & & & & & & & & \\\\    } $ ]    if we set @xmath49 , for all @xmath50 then the word associated with the point @xmath46 can be written as follows : yxxyyx .",
    "+    it is always possible to construct an @xmath1-tiling starting from an admissible boundary in the plane .",
    "the work [ ars10 ] provides a formula for a value in the tiling at the point @xmath51 .",
    "this formula is given in terms of the associated word and the following matrices : + @xmath52 , @xmath53 .",
    "+ the following theorem from [ ars10-theorem @xmath12 ] allows us to compute the variable lying at the point @xmath51 .",
    "+    given an admissible boundary @xmath43 , there exists a unique @xmath1-tiling @xmath2 of the plane extending the embedding of the boundary into the plane .",
    "for any point @xmath44 below the boundary , with an associated word @xmath55 where @xmath56 , @xmath57 , @xmath58 , the tiling @xmath2 is defined by the formula + @xmath59 .",
    "@xmath60 +    now we give an application of the notion of @xmath1-tiling to a quiver of type @xmath7 according to [ ars10 ] .",

    "the @xmath1-tiling associated with this boundary has periodicity determined by the vector @xmath87 , where @xmath88 ( or @xmath89 ) is the number of @xmath36 ( or @xmath37 , respectively ) among @xmath90 .",
    "we have also @xmath91 .",
    "we call the finite sequence @xmath92 a generator of the boundary @xmath43 . note that when extending a generator @xmath92 to a boundary @xmath86 we glue adjacent copies of the generator in a way that there is only one occurrence of @xmath93 between @xmath94 and @xmath95 ( @xmath96 )",
    ". the admissible boundary @xmath43 associated with the quiver @xmath61 of type @xmath97 is @xmath72 constructed above .",
    "its generator can be obtained by cutting the quiver @xmath61 at one of its points and reading the resulting quiver clockwise ( by reading the resulting quiver anticlockwise we obtain a generator of a boundary equivalent to @xmath43 ) .",
    "this operation creates an additional point of the quiver @xmath61 , the second copy of the point at which we cut .",
    "thus the quiver of type @xmath97 is transformed into a quiver of type @xmath98 .    in example",
    "@xmath99 let us cut the quiver @xmath100 at its point @xmath101 .",
    "we obtain in this way a quiver of type @xmath102 ( reading clockwise ) labelled as follows : @xmath103 & { 2}\\ar[r ] & 3\\ar[r ] & 4 & 1\\ar[l ] }   $ ] .",
    "if in this quiver of type @xmath104 we denote by @xmath36 the arrows oriented toward the right and by @xmath37 those oriented toward the left then we get the generator @xmath80 . +",
    "a quiver @xmath61 of type @xmath97 has @xmath105 possibilities of cutting , we choose any one of them .",
    "the quiver underlying @xmath65 is the quiver of type @xmath106 .",
    "+ we now recall the definition of a seed due to fomin and zelevinsky [ fz03 - 1.2 ]",
    ". +    let @xmath107 be a quiver ( without loops or oriented two - cycles ) with @xmath64 points and @xmath108 a set of variables called cluster variables , such that a variable @xmath109 is associated with the point @xmath50 ( with @xmath110 ) of @xmath107 .",
    "the set @xmath111 is called a cluster and the pair @xmath112 is called a seed .",
    "+    we can obtain other seeds by mutation ( see [ fz03 - 1.2 ] ) starting from the seed @xmath113 .",
    "the set of all cluster variables obtained by successive mutation generates an algebra over @xmath114 called _ cluster algebra _ which is denoted by @xmath115 . for cluster algebras",
    ", we refer to the papers [ fz02 ] , [ fz03 ] .",
    "we say that the type of a seed @xmath113 and the cluster algebra @xmath115 coincides with the type of quiver @xmath107 .",
    "if we associate a point @xmath76 of a quiver @xmath61 of type @xmath62 with the variable @xmath116 , these variables will correspond to the vertices of the boundary .",
    "then the variables of the @xmath1-tiling below the boundary are cluster variables of the cluster algebra @xmath117 .",
    "they are obtained by applying the formula of theorem @xmath78 ( see [ ars10 - 8 ] ; [ ar12 - 4.4 ] ) .",
    "+ our aim in this paper is to compute cluster variables of a cluster algebra of type @xmath0 .",
    "in this section we establish a relation between values of a frieze of type @xmath9 and some values of an @xmath1-tiling associated with a particular quiver of type @xmath7 . to this end",
    "we propose a way to associate an admissible boundary with a quiver of type @xmath9 .",
    "consider a quiver @xmath4 whose underlying graph is of type @xmath0 .",
    "we agree to label the points of @xmath4 as follows : @xmath118 & & \\\\ \\text { } & & 3 \\ar@{-}[r]\\ar@{-}[ul]\\ar@{-}[dl ] & \\ldots \\ar@{-}[r ] & ( n-1 )   & \\text { } \\\\ & 2 & & & & ( n+1)\\ar@{-}[ul ] } \\ ] ] + where a solid segment represents an arrow without its orientation .",
    "+ the _ forks _ are the full sub - quivers of @xmath4 generated by the points @xmath119 and by the points @xmath120 , respectively .",
    "+ we agree to call : + - _ fork arrows _ , the arrows of each fork , + - _ joint _ of each fork , the points @xmath11 or @xmath121 , respectively + - and _ fork vertices _ , the points @xmath101 and @xmath10 or @xmath122 and @xmath64 , respectively .",
    "+ if we associate with each vertex @xmath50 of @xmath4 a variable @xmath109 then we get the seed @xmath123 whose underlying graph can be represented by the following diagram : @xmath124 & & \\\\ \\text { } & & u_{3 } \\ar@{-}[r]\\ar@{-}[ul]\\ar@{-}[dl ] & \\ldots \\ar@{-}[r ] & u_{n-1 }   & \\text { } .\\\\ & u_{2 } & & & & u_{n+1}\\ar@{-}[ul ] } \\ ] ] + let us define a frieze on the translation quiver @xmath125 by the function + @xmath27 : @xmath126 such that for @xmath127 we have : + @xmath30 with initial variables @xmath128 and the product taken over the arrows",
    ". then all the values of the frieze are cluster variables of @xmath129 ( see [ ad11 - 1.3 ] ) .",
    "+ the study of seeds of type @xmath0 can be subdivided into different cases depending on the orientation of fork arrows . for each fork",
    "we have the following three cases : + - the fork is composed by two arrows leaving the joint , + - the fork is composed by two arrows entering the joint , + - the fork is composed by one arrow leaving the joint and another arrow entering the joint .",
    "+ it is well - known that for two seeds @xmath130 and @xmath131 , which are mutation equivalent ( we refer to [ fz03 - 8 ] for the notion of mutation equivalent ) , the cluster algebras @xmath132 and @xmath133 associated with these seeds , respectively , coincide ( see [ fz03 - 1.2 ] ) .",
    "+ our aim in this paper is to compute cluster variables of a cluster algebra of type @xmath0 independently of each other . the following lemma in [ ass - vii.5.2 ] allows us to reduce the study to one of the three different cases mentioned above .",
    "let @xmath134 and @xmath135 be two quivers having the same underlying graph @xmath136",
    ". if @xmath136 is a tree then @xmath134 and @xmath135 are mutation equivalent .",
    "@xmath60 +    in the following , @xmath137 denotes a seed of type @xmath0 with a quiver whose each fork is composed by two arrows both entering ( or leaving ) the joint .",
    "+ we denote by @xmath138 the frieze associated with the seed @xmath137 .",
    "we define in the following the notion of _ modelled quiver _ which will help us to compute the cluster variables of a cluster algebra of type @xmath0 without using iteration .",
    "we call modelled quiver @xmath139 associated with @xmath137 , the translation quiver obtained from the frieze @xmath140 as follows : + @xmath141 by gluing in @xmath140 the arrows of each shifted copy of the forks , + @xmath142 by multiplying the values assigned to vertices of the fork corresponding to the arrows that were glued in step @xmath101 .",
    "namely the arrows obtained by gluing in step @xmath101 have @xmath143 or @xmath144 as the corresponding variables .",
    "+    we give an example of a modelled quiver associated with a seed of type @xmath145 .",
    "@xmath146 & & u_{4}\\ar[dl ] & & \\\\ \\text{for the following seed of type $ \\tilde{\\mathbb{d}}_{4}$:}\\quad & & u_{3 }   & & & \\text{,}\\\\ & u_{2}\\ar[ur ] & & u_{5}\\ar[ul ] } $ ] + the frieze @xmath140 has the form : +   + and the modelled quiver @xmath147 has the form : +   +    all the squares of the form     + in @xmath139 satisfy the relation @xmath148 called the uni - modular rule , with @xmath149 .",
    "the values on the upper and bottom extreme lines in @xmath147 are products of two cluster variables ( products created by the passage from @xmath138 to @xmath147 ) .",
    "note that the pairs of cluster variables forming these products ( in the case of both arrows of a fork entering or leaving the joint ) are given by fractions whose numerators are equal and denominators coincide up to exchanging @xmath150 and @xmath151 ( or @xmath152 and @xmath153 ) , which appear in denominators with exponent one ( see [ bmr09 - 1 ] ) .",
    "therefore , a product of these two variables is of the form @xmath154 for one fork and @xmath155 for the other fork , with @xmath156 .",
    "+ then the two extreme lines in the modelled quiver @xmath147 contain the sequences of variables of the form @xmath157 for the horizontal line passing through the variable @xmath158 and of the form @xmath159 for the horizontal line passing through the variable @xmath160 . + as a consequence of the definition of a frieze , we have the following relations for all @xmath161 : @xmath162^{2 } = \\displaystyle\\frac{1}{(u_{1}u_{2})^{2}}\\phi^{2}_{k}\\phi^{2}_{k+1 } , \\hspace{3 cm}\\ ] ] @xmath163^{2 } = \\displaystyle\\frac{1}{(u_{n}u_{n+1})^{2}}\\psi^{2}_{k}\\psi^{2}_{k-1}. \\hspace{3 cm}\\ ] ] +      let @xmath4 be a quiver of type @xmath0 and * @xmath164 * be the full sub - quiver of @xmath4 generated by all points except the points @xmath10 , @xmath64 . we agree to draw @xmath164 from the left to the right in such a way that the vertices appear in increasing order .",
    "note that @xmath164 is a quiver of type @xmath165 .",
    "this leads to a way to associate a quiver of type @xmath3 with a quiver of type @xmath0 , which , in turn , will allow us to associate an admissible boundary with a quiver of type @xmath0 .    for a quiver @xmath166 of type @xmath167 ( drawn from left to right ) ,",
    "let us denote by @xmath168 the transpose of @xmath166 , that is , the quiver obtained by redrawing @xmath166 from right to left .",
    "+ with a quiver @xmath4 of type @xmath0 we associate the quiver @xmath169 of the form +   + we know that the boundary @xmath170 associated with a quiver @xmath61 of type @xmath97 is periodic and its period @xmath105 corresponds to the length of a generator @xmath65 .    for the quiver @xmath169 of type @xmath3 there is a choice of @xmath171 different generators for its associated boundary @xmath172 : one can cut at any of @xmath171 points of @xmath169 to obtain a generator .",
    "we are going to use only one of these generators to construct the admissible boundary @xmath173 associated with a quiver of type @xmath0 .",
    "the generator @xmath174 of the boundary @xmath172 is obtained by cutting the quiver @xmath169 at the point @xmath101 of its arrow @xmath175 & { 1 } }   $ ] and reading the quiver clockwise .",

    "+    let @xmath4 be a quiver of type @xmath0 whose each fork consists of two arrows both entering or both leaving the joint .",
    "the admissible boundary @xmath173 associated with @xmath4 is of the form @xmath183 , where @xmath174 is repeated infinitely many times on the left and @xmath176 is repeated infinitely many times on the right .",
    "the boundary @xmath173 is obtained by gluing to @xmath180 the generators @xmath184 periodically on the left and @xmath176 periodically on the right .",
    "note that @xmath180 is also contained in @xmath174 and @xmath176 .",
    "however the decomposition of the boundary of the form @xmath183 defines a distinguished occurrence of @xmath180 in @xmath173 .",
    "it is this occurrence of @xmath180 which we call the _ root _ of @xmath4 in @xmath173 . + we give an example showing how to associate an admissible boundary with a quiver @xmath4 of type @xmath0 .",

    "+ we now recall the notion of _ ray _ in a tiling @xmath2 from [ ars10 - 6.1 ] .",
    "this notion allows us to find the values of a frieze of type @xmath0 among values in the tiling @xmath2 below the boundary @xmath173 .",
    "+ given a mapping @xmath15 , a point @xmath192 and a nonzero vector @xmath193 , we consider the sequence @xmath194 .",

    ", we can reconstruct the modelled quiver @xmath147 associated with the seed @xmath137 by using the uni - modular rule and formulas @xmath206 and @xmath207 of remark @xmath208 .",
    "if we associate also the vertex of @xmath169 labelled @xmath209 with the variable @xmath210 then the result of this association is a seed which will be denoted by @xmath211 . its underlying graph with variables is : +   + since @xmath210 is not a cluster variable in @xmath137 , in the rest of this paper we evaluate @xmath212 .",
    "note that the generators @xmath213 and @xmath176 are obtained from @xmath169 and thus our association of variables with the points of @xmath169 naturally associates variables with the vertices of @xmath213 and @xmath176 .",
    "from now on , we denote by @xmath213 and @xmath176 the corresponding generators with variables .",
    "we denote by @xmath214 the admissible boundary @xmath173 with variables and the following theorem establishes a link between the frieze @xmath138 and the tiling associated with @xmath214 .",

    "+ consider the transpose of @xmath89 , which is @xmath227 . by a translation of parentheses toward the right , we can rewrite @xmath228 as follows : @xmath229    this allows us to rewrite the boundary in the form : @xmath230 .",
    "then the embedding of @xmath214 in the plane gives the following scheme : + @xmath231\\ar@{.}[ururr]^{^{t}s } &           \\\\ & & & & & & &   & &   & &    &    &           \\\\ & & & & &   & b\\ar@{-}[r ]   & i\\ar@{-}[r ] & j \\ar@{.}[urrur]^{^{t}\\lambda } &    &           \\\\ & & & & & & &   & &   &   &    &    &           \\\\ & & a\\ar@{.}[rrrrrrrrr]\\ar@{.}[rrrruu]^{\\lambda}\\ar@{.}[dll]^{s } & & & & & & & & & j_{k}\\ar@{.}[llluu]&&\\\\   & & & & &    &   &     &    & & &     &      \\\\   & & & & & & & & & & & & & \\\\   & & & & & & & & & & & & & \\\\ } $ ] + let us write @xmath232 for the walk on the boundary from @xmath233 to @xmath234 and @xmath235 for that from @xmath223 to @xmath236 . then the word associated with @xmath225 is of the form @xmath237 .    by construction of @xmath214 , the end point of the walk",
    "@xmath232 is the variable @xmath158 , and thus @xmath158 is also the starting vertex of @xmath235 .",
    "computing the tiling function @xmath2 from theorem @xmath78 for the point @xmath225 , gives :    @xmath238 + where @xmath239 is a product of the variables in @xmath232 except the variable @xmath158 , which are also by transposition in @xmath235 , and @xmath240 arise from the product of matrices corresponding to the walk @xmath232 .",
    "the computation gives @xmath241^{2}.\\hspace{3 cm}\\ ] ]    thus the value lying at the point @xmath225 on the diagonal ray with origin @xmath223 is a perfect square divided by @xmath158 .    to show that the value lying at a point @xmath226 on the diagonal ray with origin @xmath224 is a perfect square divided by @xmath242 we perform a similar calculation using the following form of the boundary @xmath243 .",
    "this form is obtained by noticing that the transpose of @xmath244 is @xmath245 and by a translation of parentheses toward the left , we can rewrite @xmath246 as follows : + @xmath247 + since the tiling @xmath2 ( below @xmath214 ) satisfies the uni - modular rule and since @xmath180 with variables coincides with the quiver @xmath164 with variables then by virtue of remark @xmath248 it only remains to prove that the variables on the two diagonal rays with origins @xmath223 and @xmath224 satisfy relations of the form @xmath206 and @xmath207 from remark @xmath208 .",
    "+ consider the following scheme which represents four adjacent points @xmath249 forming a square in the tiling below @xmath214 .",
    "@xmath250&d&&&&&&\\\\ & & & & & & & & & & & & & & & & & & & & & & & & \\\\ & & & & & &   & & & & & & & &    & & & & & & & & & &     \\\\ & & & & & & & & & & & &     & & c\\ar@{.}[dddd]\\ar@{.}[uuu ] &           \\\\ & & & &   & & & & & &   & &    &    &           \\\\ & & & & & & & &   & b\\ar@{-}[r ]   & i\\ar@{-}[r ] & j \\ar@{.}[urrur]^{^{t}\\lambda } &    &           \\\\ & & & &   & & & & & &   &   &    &    &           \\\\ & & \\ar@{-}[d]&&&a\\ar@{.}[lll]\\ar@{.}[rrrrrrrrr]\\ar@{.}[rrrruu]^{\\lambda } & & & & & & & & & j_{k}\\ar@{.}[llluu]&d_{k}\\ar@{.}[uuuuuuu]&\\\\   & & b ' & & & & &    &   & &    & & & & i_{k+1}\\ar@{.}[llllllllllll ] & j_{k+1 } & & & & & & & & & &     \\\\ & & & & & & & & & & & & & & & & & & & & & \\\\ } $ ] + the words associated with the points @xmath251 and @xmath252 are respectively of the form @xmath253 and @xmath254 where @xmath232 is the walk on the boundary from @xmath233 to @xmath234 and @xmath255 is that from @xmath256 to @xmath234 .",
    "+ by definition of @xmath214 , the point @xmath257 is on the diagonal ray with origin @xmath258 .",
    "we need to prove that each value @xmath259 on this diagonal satisfies the relation : @xmath260^{2 } = t(j_{k})t(j_{k+1 } ) . \\hspace{3",
    "cm}\\ ] ]    to this end , we compute the values lying at the points @xmath251 and @xmath252",
    ". + due to @xmath261 , we have : @xmath262^{2 } , \\nonumber \\\\",
    "t(j_{k+1 } ) & = & \\displaystyle\\frac{1}{u_{1}u_{2}}\\left[\\frac{\\tilde{a}+\\tilde{b}}{\\tilde{\\gamma}}\\right]^{2}. \\nonumber \\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    for the two remaining variables , the application of the map @xmath2 gives :    @xmath263 , \\nonumber \\\\",
    "t(i_{k+1 } ) & = & \\displaystyle\\frac{1}{(u_{1}u_{2})^{2}\\gamma \\tilde{\\gamma}}\\left ( \\tilde{a},\\tilde{b}\\right )   \\left ( \\begin{array}{cccccc } u_{1}u_{2 } &   & 1\\\\ 0 &   & 1 \\\\ \\end{array } \\right ) \\left ( \\begin{array}{cccccc } 1 &   & 1   \\\\ 0 &   & u_{1}u_{2}\\\\ \\end{array } \\right)\\left ( \\begin{array}{cccccc } a \\\\ b \\\\",
    "\\end{array } \\right ) \\nonumber \\\\ & = & \\displaystyle\\frac{1}{u_{1}u_{2}\\gamma\\tilde{\\gamma } } \\left[\\tilde{a}(a + 2b ) + b\\tilde{b}\\right ] .",
    "\\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    then we have @xmath264 . according to the uni - modular rule in the tiling @xmath265 , therefore we get @xmath266 + let us compute now @xmath267 + @xmath268 + 1 \\nonumber \\\\ & = & \\displaystyle\\frac{1}{u_{1}u_{2}\\gamma \\tilde{\\gamma } } \\left[a(\\tilde{a } + 2\\tilde{b } ) + b\\tilde{b } + u_{1}u_{2}\\gamma \\tilde{\\gamma}\\right ] \\nonumber \\\\ & = & \\displaystyle\\frac{1}{u_{1}u_{2}\\gamma \\tilde{\\gamma}}\\left[a(\\tilde{a } + 2\\tilde{b } ) + b\\tilde{b } + ( \\tilde{a}b - a\\tilde{b})\\right ] \\nonumber \\\\ & = & \\displaystyle\\frac{(a + b ) ( \\tilde{a}+\\tilde{b } ) } { u_{1}u_{2}\\gamma \\tilde{\\gamma } } .",
    "\\nonumber   \\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    then we have @xmath269^{2 } & = & \\displaystyle\\frac{(a + b)^{2}}{u_{1}u_{2}\\gamma^{2 } } \\times \\displaystyle\\frac{(\\tilde{a } + \\tilde{b})^{2}}{u_{1}u_{2 } \\tilde{\\gamma}^{2 } } \\nonumber \\\\   & = & t(j_{k})t(j_{k+1 } ) .",
    "\\nonumber   \\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    we prove in the same way that the sequence of the points @xmath270 lying on the diagonal ray with origin @xmath271 satisfies the relation : @xmath272^{2 } =   t(j'_{k})t(j'_{k-1 } ) .",
    "\\hspace{3 cm}\\ ] ]    all the squares in the oblique band delimited by the diagonal rays with origins @xmath223 and @xmath224 satisfy the uni - modular rule due to properties of the @xmath1-tiling @xmath2 .",
    "this and relations @xmath273 and @xmath274 , by virtue of remark @xmath248 , allows us to conclude that the diagonal rays with origins at the vertices of the root @xmath180 of the quiver @xmath4 in @xmath214 coincide with horizontal lines of the modelled quiver @xmath147 associated with the seed @xmath275 @xmath60 +    we proved theorem @xmath276 for a seed @xmath137 whose associated quiver has forks composed by two arrows entering ( or leaving ) the joint . for a seed @xmath131",
    "whose associated quiver @xmath135 has at least one fork consisting of one arrow entering and one arrow leaving the joint there are two possibilities .",
    "one possibility is to perform a mutation on one of the fork vertices and thus reduce this case to the one considered in the proof .",
    "another possibility is to work directly with the seed @xmath277 . in this case",
    "the given proof can easily be modified , namely one has to associate with the vertex labelled by @xmath278 ( or @xmath279 ) in @xmath280 the variable @xmath281 ( or @xmath282 ) and to consider the following underlying graph for @xmath280 with variables : + @xmath283 & u_{3 } \\ar@{-}[r ] & u_{4 } \\ldots & u_{n-1 } \\ar@{-}[l ] & u_{n}u_{n+1 } \\ar@{-}[l ] &   } $ ] + or @xmath284 & u_{3 } \\ar@{-}[r ] & u_{4 } \\ldots & u_{n-1 } \\ar@{-}[l ] & \\displaystyle\\left ( \\frac{u_{n+1}(1+u_{n-1})}{u_{n}}\\right )   \\ar@{-}[l ] } $ ] , respectively .",
    "let @xmath285 be a seed with @xmath4 of type @xmath0 with forks composed by two arrows both entering or both leaving the joint .",
    "in this section we compute cluster variables of the cluster algebra @xmath286 of type @xmath0 by an explicit formula using matrix product ( from theorem @xmath78 ) and by using signed continuant polynomials .",
    "+ there are two kinds of cluster variables of a cluster algebra @xmath286 of type @xmath287 .",
    "cluster variables of @xmath286 either are transjective and correspond to those lying in the translation quiver @xmath125 as embedded in the auslander - reiten quiver of the cluster category or are nontransjective and correspond to those lying on the tubes ( see [ ss - x.1 ] ) .",
    "+    [ [ computation - of - transjective - cluster - variables - of - a - cluster - algebra - of - type - tildemathbbd_n ] ] computation of transjective cluster variables of a cluster algebra of type @xmath0 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~    it is well - known , see [ ars10 ] and also [ ad11 ] that for @xmath288 , the values contained in the frieze @xmath138 give all transjective cluster variables of @xmath286 . therefore the values of the frieze at the points of the modelled quiver @xmath147 associated with the seed @xmath137 are either transjective cluster variables of @xmath286 or products of two transjective cluster variables of @xmath286 .        in the @xmath1-tiling @xmath2 , the variables lying on diagonal rays with origins @xmath289 , respectively , which are vertices of the root @xmath180 in @xmath214 , are the transjective cluster variables .",
    "their computation is obtained by applying the formula of theorem @xmath78 .    the variables lying on the diagonal rays with origins @xmath158 or @xmath160 , respectively , which are extreme vertices of the root @xmath180 in @xmath214 , are products of two transjective cluster variables ( products created by the passage from @xmath138 to @xmath147 ) .",
    "recall that the pairs of cluster variables forming these products are given by fractions whose numerators are equal and denominators coincide up to exchanging @xmath150 and @xmath151 ( or @xmath152 and @xmath153 ) , which appear in denominators with exponent one ( see [ bmr09 - 1 ] ) .",
    "therefore , a product of these two transjective variables is a perfect square divided by @xmath158 ( or @xmath160 , respectively ) .    each value @xmath290 lying on the diagonal rays with origins @xmath158 or @xmath160 gives rise to two transjective cluster variables @xmath291 and @xmath196 as follows : + @xmath292 where + @xmath293^{\\dfrac{1}{2}}$ ] and + @xmath294^{\\dfrac{1}{2}}$ ] for the diagonal ray with origin @xmath158 or + @xmath295^{\\dfrac{1}{2}}$ ] and + @xmath296^{\\dfrac{1}{2}}$ ] for the diagonal ray with origin @xmath160 .",
    "@xmath60 +      [ [ computation - of - nontransjective - cluster - variables - of - cluster - algebra - of - type - tildemathbbd ] ] computation of nontransjective cluster variables of cluster algebra of type @xmath9 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~    according to theorem @xmath276 the correspondence between a frieze associated with a seed @xmath137 of type @xmath0 and an @xmath1-tiling associated with a particular seed of type @xmath3 , allows us to regard transjective variables of the cluster algebra @xmath286 of type @xmath0 as those of a particular type @xmath3 .",
    "this suggests the idea of looking for nontransjective variables of the cluster algebra @xmath286 also among cluster variables of the same cluster algebra of type @xmath3 . to this end",
    "we introduce a property of @xmath1-tilings from [ br10- formula @xmath274 ] .",
    "+      we call @xmath302 the _ linearization coefficient _ of column @xmath303 .",
    "there is a similar property and definition for three successive rows @xmath304 and @xmath305 .",
    "+ let @xmath306 be elements of some ring @xmath307 , the signed continuant polynomials ( see [ ar12 - 2.1 ] ) are defined recursively as follows : + @xmath308 setting @xmath309 and @xmath310 .",
    "it is known according to [ ar12-theorem @xmath311 that cluster variables of a cluster algebra of type @xmath7 either appear as elements of the corresponding @xmath1-tiling , or as continuant polynomials of the linearization coefficients of the @xmath1-tiling .",
    "we recall here the technique of computation of the nontransjective cluster variables of cluster algebra of type @xmath7 according to [ ar12 ] .",
    "we use the linearization coefficients of columns , the case of rows being analogous .",
    "we need a new concept of _ word _ associated with a set of successive columns .",
    "+    let @xmath312 be a finite set of successive columns of the tiling @xmath2 associated with a boundary @xmath43 .",
    "we call _ word associated with the set @xmath313 _ , the portion of the boundary @xmath43 between its intersections with the columns @xmath314 augmented with one step to the left and one to the right .    consider the scheme of example @xmath315 and let @xmath313 be the set of successive columns containing the variables from @xmath316 to @xmath93 .",
    "the word associated with this set @xmath313 of columns is : @xmath317 .",
    "+      consider an @xmath1-tiling @xmath2 associated with some boundary @xmath43 with variables in @xmath13 .",
    "let @xmath318 be @xmath75 successive columns of the tiling @xmath2 , with linearization coefficients @xmath319 .",
    "let @xmath320 , @xmath56 , @xmath57 , @xmath58 be the word associated with this set of columns . then the signed continuant polynomial @xmath321 is equal to + @xmath322 .",
    "@xmath60 +    we recall that in the case @xmath97 with @xmath88 clockwise oriented arrows and @xmath89 anti - clockwise oriented arrows , the nontransjective cluster variables are lying on two tubes of rank @xmath88 and @xmath89 ( see [ ss - xiii.2.2 ] ) . in case",
    "@xmath0 nontransjective variables lie on three tubes such that two are of rank @xmath10 and the third one is of rank @xmath323 ( see [ ss - xiii.2.2 ] ) .",
    "consider our quiver @xmath169 of type @xmath324 , with @xmath325 , which is of the form : +   + the analysis of orientation of arrows of @xmath169 gives us the equation @xmath326 . from this and the equation @xmath325",

    "we shall prove that the tube of rank @xmath89 in a particular case @xmath3 corresponding to the seed @xmath211 with @xmath329 can be identified with the tube of rank @xmath323 in the case @xmath0 .    according to [ d10-theorem @xmath330",
    ", it is enough to know the variables lying on the mouth of a tube to determine all the variables lying on this tube . + we prove the following theorem which allows us to compute the @xmath323 nontransjective cluster variables lying on the mouth of the tube of rank @xmath323 in the case @xmath0 .",
    "+    let @xmath331 be an integer , @xmath137 a seed of type @xmath0 and @xmath211 the seed of type @xmath3 associated with @xmath137 .",
    "the tube of rank @xmath332 containing nontransjective variables of the cluster algebra @xmath333 with @xmath329 coincides with the tube of rank @xmath323 containing nontransjective cluster variables of the cluster algebra @xmath286 of type @xmath0 .    before the proof of theorem @xmath334",
    ", we recall formula @xmath335 from [ adss12 - 1.3 ] , which we are going to use to compute variables lying on the mouths of tubes . for any locally finite quiver @xmath4 with variables ( here @xmath4 is a quiver of type @xmath0 ) , we define a family of matrices with coefficients in @xmath336 $ ] as follows : + for any arrow @xmath337 in @xmath134 we set : + @xmath338 and @xmath339 .",

    "+ we define @xmath345,\\ ] ] where @xmath346 .",

    "* proof of theorem 4.6 *          it is enough to prove , according to [ d10 - 5.1 ] , that the variables lying on the mouth of the tube of rank @xmath332 in case @xmath3 corresponding to the seed @xmath211 with @xmath329 are all the @xmath323 nontransjective cluster variables lying on the mouth of the tube of rank @xmath323 in the case of the seed @xmath137 of type @xmath0 .",
    "according to [ ad11 - 1.3 ] , the nontransjective cluster variables of cluster algebra of type @xmath0 lying on the mouth of the tube of rank @xmath323 correspond to simple @xmath353-modules @xmath354 associated with points between the two joints of forks inclusively , that is with the points @xmath355 .",
    "then we obtain @xmath356 simple @xmath353-modules lying on the mouth of the tube .",
    "+ to compute the cluster variables of the cluster algebra @xmath286 of type @xmath0 corresponding to these simple modules , we identify each point with a walk of length @xmath357 and apply formula @xmath358 .",
    "it is easy to see that the obtained variables are equal to the linearization coefficients of columns of the tiling @xmath2 passing through the vertices @xmath359 of the root @xmath180 for our orientation of @xmath4 . on the other hand we know [ ar12 ] that the linearization coefficients of rows and columns of the @xmath1-tiling @xmath2 below the boundary @xmath214 are the variables lying on the mouths of tubes of rank @xmath88 and @xmath89 , respectively , of the auslander - reiten quiver corresponding to @xmath169 of type @xmath3 .",
    "therefore we conclude that the @xmath356 cluster variables of cluster algebra of type @xmath0 obtained on the mouth of the tube of rank @xmath323 coincide with the @xmath356 variables on the mouth of the tube of rank @xmath332 in case @xmath3 and are set in the same order .",
    "+ thus we have found @xmath356 out of @xmath323 cluster variables lying on the mouth of the tube in the case @xmath286 of type @xmath0 . to compute the @xmath323th cluster variable we use the existence of linear recurrence relations between the corresponding values of the frieze @xmath138 at a joint of a fork and its neighbours from [ ks11 - 6 ] .",
    "namely , we denote by @xmath360 the auslander - reiten translation ( see [ ass - iv.2.3 ] ) , @xmath361 and by @xmath362 ( note that all cluster variables lying on the mouth of a tube of rank @xmath323 are of this form ) the image by the caldero - chapoton map ( see [ cc06 ] ) of the @xmath353-module @xmath363 . corresponding to the sequence",
    "@xmath364 associated with the joint @xmath11 of the quiver @xmath4 , we get the following relation : @xmath365    rewriting this relation as follows : @xmath366 , one can see that each variable @xmath367 lying on the mouth of the tube is the linearization coefficient of a column passing through the variable @xmath364 in the @xmath1-tiling @xmath2 defined by the boundary @xmath214 .",
    "this allows us to conclude that the @xmath323th cluster variable also corresponds to a linearization coefficient in the @xmath1-tiling @xmath2 .",
    "thus the @xmath323 cluster variables of the cluster algebra @xmath286 of type @xmath0 lying on the mouth of the tube of rank @xmath323 are equal to the linearization coefficients of columns passing through the points in the tiling below the boundary @xmath214 which correspond to the joints of the forks in the quiver @xmath140 .",
    "( recall [ ar12 ] that the sequence of linearization coefficients of the columns of the @xmath1-tiling corresponding to a quiver of type @xmath97 is periodic with the period @xmath89 .",
    "since in our case @xmath328 , there are only @xmath323 such coefficients . )",
    "thus we identify the tube of rank @xmath332 in the case @xmath3 ( corresponding to the cluster algebra @xmath333 with @xmath329 ) with the tube of rank @xmath323 in case @xmath0 ( corresponding to the cluster algebra @xmath286 ) .",
    "@xmath60 +    let @xmath368 be the signed continuant polynomial , @xmath369 with @xmath370 , be a variable of depth @xmath122 on the tube and @xmath371 be a variable lying on the mouth of the tube . according to [ ad11 - 3.5 ] the variables lying on a tube with rank @xmath372",
    "are related by the following relation @xmath373 .",

    "+ we do this by interpreting the results on quiver representations from [ ss - xiii-2.6-a and b ] in terms of cluster variables .",

    "+ the cluster variables in these three positions are computed as follows .",
    "+ the words associated with @xmath380 , @xmath382 and @xmath381 are @xmath383 , + @xmath384 and @xmath385 .",
    "+ then we have , by applying theorem @xmath78 , the following results : + @xmath386      @xmath380 and @xmath381 being placed on the bottom and upper lines in @xmath147 , we write these values in the form of a product of two transjective cluster variables as in corollary @xmath388 above .",
    "the other position corresponds to the following transjective cluster variable of type @xmath145 : + @xmath389    we compute thus all transjective cluster variables of cluster algebra of type @xmath145 by this method .",
    "+ we compute now nontransjective cluster variables of cluster algebra of type @xmath145 . because @xmath390 , these cluster variables all lie in tubes of rank @xmath10",
    ".    for one of these tubes , say @xmath391 , we have two nontransjective cluster variables @xmath392 and @xmath393 on the mouth .",
    "these variables are given by the linearization coefficients of columns of the @xmath1-tiling passing through points corresponding to the joints of forks in @xmath138 .",
    "these cluster variables can also be obtained by applying the formula of theorem @xmath394 .",
    "we choose to use theorem @xmath394 to compute the linearization coefficient @xmath392 of the column passing through the vertex @xmath258 of the root @xmath180 and to use proposition @xmath395 to compute the linearization coefficient @xmath393 of the column passing through @xmath382 .",
    "+ for the computation of @xmath392 we apply theorem @xmath394 .",
    "that is , first we need to determine the word associated with the column containing the vertex @xmath258 of the root @xmath180 . according to the embedding of the boundary @xmath214 in the plane ,",
    "this word is : + @xmath396 applying the formula of theorem @xmath394 to this word we obtain : + @xmath397    we apply proposition @xmath395 to compute the linearization coefficient @xmath393 of the column passing through the variable @xmath382 .",
    "let us calculate @xmath393 at the vertex @xmath258 at the intersection of the column containing @xmath382 with the boundary @xmath214 .",
    "then we have : + @xmath398 = \\frac { u_{1}u_{2}u_{4}u_{5 } + ( 1+u_{3})^{2 } } { u_{1}u_{2}u_{3 } } $ ] .",
    "+ thus , @xmath392 and @xmath393 are nontransjective cluster variables lying on the mouth of the tube @xmath391 .",

    ", we obtain the corresponding nontransjective cluster variables @xmath404 and @xmath405 :        thus @xmath404 and @xmath405 are the nontransjective cluster variables lying on the mouth of @xmath399 . + for the third tube @xmath408 , we associate the modules lying on the mouth with the following reduced walks from @xmath150 to @xmath401 and from @xmath151 to @xmath400 : @xmath409 and @xmath410 . by applying formula @xmath358 , we obtain the corresponding nontransjective cluster variables @xmath411 and @xmath412 :          acknowledgements .",
    "the author is grateful to ibrahim assem and vasilisa shramchenko for useful discussions and careful reading of the manuscript and also to the department of mathematics of the university of sherbrooke where this work was done .",
    "the author gratefully acknowledges support from cida ( canadian international development agency ) fellowship .",
    "i. assem , d. simson and a. skowroski , _ elements of the representation theory of associative algebras 1 : techniques of representation theory _ , london mathematical society student texts 65 , cambridge university press , ( 2006 ) .",
    "d. simson , a. skowroski , elements of the representation theory of associative algebras , volume 2 : tubes and concealed algebras of euclidean type , in:_london mathematical society student texts _ , vol .",
    "71 , _ cambridge university press _ , 2007 ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> in this article , we establish a relation between the values of a frieze of type @xmath0 and some values of an @xmath1-tiling @xmath2 associated with a particular quiver of type @xmath3 . </S>",
    "<S> this relation allows us to compute , independently of each other , all the cluster variables in the cluster algebra associated with a quiver @xmath4 of type @xmath5    * mathematics subject classification ( 2010 ) * : 13f60 , 16g20 .    </S>",
    "<S> * keywords * : cluster algebras , representations of quivers . </S>"
  ]
}
